_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Equipment changes, MOC -23-2014 product pump back pressure valve, MOC 23-013 level sensor to demethanizer. .

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Energy Transfer LP
Sale Ranch Gas Plant
Stanton, Texas

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)

Introduction and Policies
Energy Transfer LP is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Energy Transfers management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 
The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency planning and response activities in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and continuous improvement efforts to improve safety at the facility.
Non-Responding Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Energy Transfer owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Stanton, Texas.  The Sale Ranch Gas Plant compresses and treats natural gas to produce residue gas (methane) and natural gas liquids (NGL).  After processing, the residue gas and NGL exit the plant via product pipelines. 
Pre-treated, sweet field gas enters the pant via a pipeline, is dehydrated, and sent to the NGL recovery plant. At the recovery plant, gas is routed to a demethanizer tower, which separates it into a residue gas product stream and an NGL product stream. The NGL stream is purified using an amine treater, which removes carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide. Sale Ranch Gas Plant uses a flare to burn waste acid gas generated by the amine treatment system. NGL is then pumped into the sales pipeline for further fractionation downstream. Residue gas is also transported off-site via the sales pipeline.  
The RMP flam

mable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are the flammable mixture comprised of methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane, and pentane, which is being processed through the plant; as well as propane, which is used as refrigerant in the cryogenic process. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  
Energy Transfer has determined that the gas plant should be considered one process under the RMP rule.  This facility has one process (as defined by the regulation) consisting of a flammable mixture and propane.  Although the systems containing the flammable mixture and the propane are not interconnected, an incident in one of the systems could trigger a release in the other system, therefore, the two systems should be considered one process (see definition of process at 40 CFR 68.3). 
Energy Transfer has determined that SRGP is classified as a Program Level 3 facility under the RMP regulation because the nearest public receptor is within the worst-case scenario flammable endpoint radius and the facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 
The accidental release prevention and emergency planning and response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by Energy Transfer. These high standards include: 
-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility, operator training, and intervention.
Prevention Program
The Sale Ranch Gas Plant is operating under a prevention program that involves identifying and taking s

teps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include: 
-	Providing overpressure relief valves on pressurized vessels.
-	Providing level transmitters and alarms on vessels to help prevent overfilling.
-	Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbon vapors by having a continuous flare.
-	Providing automated and manual valves to isolate portions of the process.
-	Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible explosive environment.
-	Installing fire eye detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible fire.
-	Installing security lighting to facilitate observation of the entire facility.
-	Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility 24/7/365.
-	Providing an evacuation alarm system in order to safely evacuate personnel from the facility.
-	Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.
	Five-Year Accident History
	No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or significant property damage or known offsite impacts such as death, injury, property damage, shelter in place, evacuation, or environmental damage from a regulated substance has occurred at the facility within the last five years.	
	Emergency Planning and Response Program
	The facility will conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility will be the Martin County Sheriffs Department.  The Plant Management is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions when an incident occurs within the facility.  An emergency response program is in place at the facility which has been coordinated with local officials.  The Sale Ranch Gas Pla

nt is designated as a non-responding stationary source.  The emergency planning and response program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.
	Continuous Safety Improvement Efforts
	Energy Transfers Environmental, Health, and Safety Management System forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:
-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, or equipment are considered.
-	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) process serves as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential process hazards and verification of safeguards, thereby leading to continual improvements in process safety and safe work practices.
-	The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
-	Incident Investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective and/or preventative measures are taken, as applicable, following an incident.  This ensures that process design, operating equipment, and operating and maintenance safe work practices are evaluated to determine changes needed to prevent the recurrence of an incident.
-	Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements with any action items tracked to completion.
-	An annual dialogue with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department will ensure a readiness to respond to potential emergencies, as well to implement improvements as the need develops.
